media.description:
I had boiled water at room temperature in the vacuum chamber, 
and I knew that popcorn pops partly because of the water inside turning to steam,
so I wondered if popcorn would pop at room temperature in a vacuum.

So I tried.
media.title: 20151205_163756.jpg

media.description: It's hard to see because the boiling water steamed up the lid.
media.title: 20151205_165607.jpg

media.description:
Pulled a vacuum down to less than -80 kPa.
Water boiled, corn did not pop.

The internet would later let me know that that a popcorn shell can withstand around 900 kPa of pressure and the heat is necessary to do something with the starch.  At that point I kind of glazed over and started thinking how I could warm something in the vacuum chamber.
media.title: 20151205_165614.jpg

media.description:
Pulled a vacuum down to less than -80 kPa.
Water boiled, corn did not pop.
media.title: 20151205_165835.jpg

media.description:
I needed to create a heater on which to cook the popcorn.
I dug through my resistors until I found this 2 ohm power resistor which I promptly hooked up to a 12V landscape light transformer.
media.title: 20151213_172323.jpg

media.description:
This is the first popcorn test rig.
Initially I let a little of the smoke out of the resistor and determined that I had to manually turn the transformer on and off to keep the resistor from completely destroying itself.  I found a rate that got just over the 420 degree F limit of my hand held thermometer.
I also discovered that popcorn on a heat source without oil will fizzle, split, and burn without popping.
media.title: 20151213_172329.jpg

media.description: So I got some cooking oil and aluminum foil.
media.title: 20151213_173527.jpg

media.description: I made a little frying pan on top of my heat source out of the foil
media.title: 20151213_173803.jpg

media.description: I put a little oil in my makeshift pan
media.title: 20151213_174108.jpg

media.description: and added one kernel of corn
media.title: 20151213_174134.jpg

media.description: I cooked it until it popped which took just a few minutes of manually switching the power supply on and off.
media.title: 20151213_174519.jpg

media.description: Here is the popcorn on the floor.
media.title: 20151213_174524.jpg

media.description:
I needed to extend the electrical connection into the vacuum chamber.  
 I didn't want to drill through the side of the chamber or anything unless I absolutely had to, so I used these strips of flexible PCB.
media.title: 20151213_174911.jpg

media.description:
Here is the resistor heat source 
hooked up to test clips
held in a helping hand
wired through the flexible printed circuit board.
media.title: 20151213_175020.jpg

media.description:
The electrical connections will go between the polycarbonate and rubber gasket like this.
The only problem is that I won't be able to watch the temperature as closely.
media.title: 20151213_175323.jpg

media.description: Ready to fire up the experiment
media.title: 20151213_175553.jpg

media.description:
You can see the pressure gauge and the oil boiling before 

 * POP *
media.title: 20151213_180139.mp4

media.description:
Voila!
I got the popcorn to pop in the vacuum chamber at -80 kPa!
media.title: 20151213_180257.jpg

media.description:
I wasn't sure what the popcorn would do in a sudden compression environment so I pulled the hose of the tank.
You can clearly see the pressure return to the normal approximate 14 psi and the corn blows around but does not visibly change in size or appearance.
media.title: 20151213_180304.mp4

media.description: As expected, the splattering oil made a mess on the inside of the chamber, you can see it splattered on the inside of the lid here.
media.title: 20151213_180343.jpg

media.description:
OK, so my sample size is one control and one experiment which is pretty small so the margin of error is large but the kernel popped on the bench is on the left and the one popped in a vacuum is on the right.  

The vacuum popped popcorn is much larger and sure looks fluffier.
media.title: 20151213_180427.jpg

media.description:
OK, so my sample size is one control and one experiment which is pretty small so the margin of error is large but the kernel popped on the bench is on the left and the one popped in a vacuum is on the right.  

The vacuum popped popcorn is much larger and sure looks fluffier.

They were delicious.
media.title: 20151213_180438.jpg
